channel.title: Hard drive is causing arch linux to refuse to boot
channel.description:
I probably make no sense in this topic, please bare with me.
Basically, as many probably already know I've had problems booting arch linux recently, it returned the following error: http://i.imgur.com/RLpFN.jpg (Slightly large image hence why it's not embedded)
There's definitely a problem with my hard drive...
I did numerous things to fix it however this did not work so I formatted all my linux partitions (boot,swap and root) but the arch linux live cd also returns the exact same error. I've ran fsck and chkdsk several times (using another linux live cd and windows respectively) and they reported faulty sectors, so I forced them to fix them and the error is still reported at boot.
So, I pose the question whether the disk should be binned or is there still live in it since windows is happy to boot with it!
ps, it's a 2.5' 160gb seagate drive from a netbook.

item.title: Hard drive is causing arch linux to refuse to boot
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

I should mention it’s a 2.5’ sata drive but it’s in ide emulation mode so the connectors are probably fine. The live cd had no problem booting without the drive in the machine, so I can deduct that it must either be the hard drive itself or the controller. I’ll see if I can grab another drive, stick it in and see the results.

Read full topic
item.source: Hard drive is causing arch linux to refuse to boot

item.title: Hard drive is causing arch linux to refuse to boot
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

DMA = Direct memory access (or Dynamic memory allocation?)
UDMA = http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UDMA (accessing data on an ATA drive)

With those definitions, it failed to “READ DMA EXT,” which perhaps means it failed to read direct memory access. This could be an issue with your memory, the hard drive, the connectors, or controllers. Also note of the “Buffer I/O error on device sda.”

Read full topic
item.source: Hard drive is causing arch linux to refuse to boot
